channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudis Bankroll Taliban, Even as King Officially Supports Afghan Government
item.media:description: A hilltop overlooking Kabul, where a $100 million Saudi-funded mosque and education complex was to be built. Construction was scheduled for completion this year, but the hilltop site remains a dusty lot where boys fly kites and drug addicts crouch beside a cemetery wall.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Saudi Arabia has voiced support for American efforts to nourish Afghanistan’s democracy, but it has also lavishly funded Sunni extremism under various guises.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Like Trump, Europe’s Populists Win Big With Rural Voters
item.media:description: “This area has always been conservative, always,” Joszef Grochowski, mayor of Kulesze Koscielne, said. “The ethos of the people who live here is work and faith.”
item.media:credit: Piotr Malecki for The New York Times
item.description: Anti-establishment parties are on the move, tapping into rural discontent and exploiting rural resentments against urban residents viewed as elites.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Angela Merkel Calls for Ban on Full-Face Veils in Germany
item.description: Accepting her party’s nomination as their candidate for another four-year term, the chancellor also made a promise that Shariah law would never replace German justice.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Russia Updates Plan to Counter Cyberattacks and Foreign Influence
item.description: The new document sketches out what the Kremlin sees as the main threats posed by foreign influences to its security and national interests.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: E.U. Leaders Talk Tough on ‘Brexit’ and Warn That Time Is Short
item.media:description: Michel Barnier, a lead negotiator for the European Union, said on Tuesday in Brussels that “cherry picking is not an option” for Britain.
item.description: One of the bloc’s chief negotiators said that there would be no “cherry picking” by Britain and that a deal needed to be reached within 18 months of talks opening.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Plane Carrying More Than 40 People Crashes in Pakistan
item.description: An initial report from the airline listed 42 passengers, including a former pop singer, and five crew members on the plane. The cause of the crash was not immediately known.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Indonesia Earthquake Kills Almost 100 in Aceh Province
item.description: The temblor had a preliminary magnitude of 6.5 and struck while many were asleep.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Kofi Annan, in Myanmar, Voices Concern Over Reported Abuses of Rohingya
item.description: Mr. Annan, the former head of the United Nations who leads a commission that was formed to study conditions in restive Rakhine State, urged security services to follow the “rule of law.”
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Girl Tweeting From Aleppo Draws Enormous Sympathy, but Doubts Follow
item.description: Bana al-Abed, 7, has more than 220,000 followers on Twitter, where she chronicles the deprivations of a child in war-torn Syria. But she has also raised questions of authenticity.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE, MEGAN SPECIA and SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: Syrian Forces Said to Drive Deeper Into Rebel-Held Aleppo
item.media:description: Bodies collected from a building in eastern Aleppo, Syria, on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Mohammed Abu Jaafar, via Associated Press
item.description: Anti-government activists in the city were sending increasingly desperate messages about being killed or arrested, and civilians called for safe passage out.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Brazil’s Senate Leader Refuses Justice’s Order to Step Down
item.description: Legal scholars said the Supreme Court could issue a warrant for the arrest of the Senate chief, Renan Calheiros, potentially causing a full-blown constitutional crisis.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Itamatatuba Journal: A Floating Courthouse Takes the Rule of Law to Brazil’s Frontier
item.media:description: The King Benedict, a riverboat that serves as a floating courtroom on the Amazon River, during its visit to Itamatatuba, Brazil.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: A three-story riverboat braves choppy currents, malarial mosquitoes and the threat of pirates to provide justice on the Amazon.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Jubilant Libyan Militias Declare Victory Over ISIS in Surt
item.media:description: A Libyan fighter allied with the United Nations-backed government waved the country’s flag from the ruins of a house in Surt after militias said they had driven out the Islamic State.
item.description: The apparent end to the battle was another defeat for the Islamic State as its ambitions for a militant empire buckle on multiple fronts.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Ghana Presidential Vote Hinges on Economic Perceptions
item.media:description: Nana Akufo-Addo, the front-runner opposition presidential candidate, at a campaign rally in Accra on Sunday.
item.description: President John Mahama is emphasizing infrastructure projects ahead of the Wednesday vote. His opponent, Nana Akufo-Addo, says he can kick-start the economy.
item.dc:creator: SEAN LYNGAAS and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: What in the World: Who Haunts U.K. Ghost Trains? Railway Enthusiasts
item.media:description: The phrase “ghost train” might evoke an eerie, fantastical image, but in Britain, it’s a money-saving strategy for railroad companies.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lena Bush; Photo by Antonio Mingot
item.description: The trains, bureaucratic curiosities that run infrequently and visit forgotten stations, are a draw for railroad fans, who try to ride as many as possible.
item.dc:creator: DES SHOE

item.title: Sinosphere: How Trump’s Call With Taiwan Could Affect U.S. Goals in Asia
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump in Cincinnati last week. Mr. Trump’s call with President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan shattered decades of diplomatic protocol and raised questions about his strategy toward China.
item.description: Paul Haenle, a retired Army officer who served on the National Security Council, gauges the consequences of the president-elect’s action.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Ship Capsizes Off Yemen With Nearly 60 People Aboard
item.description: Four passengers on the ship, which was sailing from Al Mukalla, Yemen, to the remote island of Socotra, were rescued, and officials are still looking for survivors.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI

item.title: Saudi Court Orders Executions for 15 Accused of Spying for Iran
item.description: The sentences came as the rivalry between the countries fuels conflicts across the Middle East. Human rights groups criticized the trial.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Iran’s President Says Donald Trump Can’t Tear Up Nuclear Pact
item.description: In a nationally televised speech, President Hassan Rouhani said: “America is our enemy; we have no doubt about this. The Americans want to put as much pressure on us as they can.”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: A Proposal for a Canadian National Bird Ruffles Feathers
item.media:description: The gray jay is the Royal Canadian Geographic Society’s choice for Canada’s national bird.
item.description: The Royal Canadian Geographic Society assembled experts who chose the little-seen gray jay, though the popular vote went for the loon.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: German Court Upholds Nuclear Exit but Orders Compensation for Power Companies
item.media:description: The Federal Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe, Germany, ruled on Tuesday that power companies must be compensated for losses resulting from the government’s decision to close nuclear plants.
item.media:credit: Uli Deck/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The ruling brings to an end a bitter dispute between the government and energy firms over the decision in 2011 to abandon nuclear power in the wake of a nuclear disaster in Japan.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Dominic Ongwen, Ugandan Rebel Leader, Denies Charges at I.C.C. Trial
item.description: The commander in the Lord’s Resistance Army, a rebel group in central Africa, was charged in The Hague with 70 war crimes and crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Europe Presses American Tech Companies to Tackle Hate Speech
item.media:description: Nowar al-Husari, an illustrator from Syria, used Facebook on his mobile phone in Berlin. Facebook is facing mounting pressure from German lawmakers to clamp down on hate speech.
item.media:credit: Phil Moore for The New York Times
item.description: A report published by European officials said that only 40 percent of online material flagged as offensive was reviewed within 24 hours.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Roman Polanski Extradition Request Rejected by Poland’s Supreme Court
item.media:description: Roman Polanski at a court hearing in Krakow, Poland, in 2015. The Krakow prosecutor’s office had sought Mr. Polanski’s extradition on behalf of the United States.
item.description: The Oscar-winning filmmaker is wanted in the United States over a decades-old conviction for having sex with a 13-year-old girl.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: South Korea’s Leader Offers to Quit in April, but It’s Unlikely to Be Enough
item.media:description: A demonstrator supporting President Park Geun-hye of South Korea wept listening to the national anthem during a rally opposing her impeachment on Tuesday in Seoul, the capital.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye now sees an impeachment vote in her corruption scandal as inevitable, a party colleague says, and it could come as early as Friday.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Currency Didn’t Really Drop, Despite Jitters Over Trump
item.media:description: A billboard displaying United States currency outside a bank in Beijing in November.
item.description: Some data services showed that the renminbi had been sharply devalued overnight, but a technical problem, not a decision by China, was responsible for the error.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: Confessions Made Under Duress Tarnish China’s Graft Fight, Report Says
item.media:description: Zhou Wangyan, a former land bureau official in Liling, China, in 2014. Mr. Zhou said that he was detained and tortured under the Communist Party’s secretive “shuanggui” program. A report released Tuesday by Human Rights Watch said that such claims were far from uncommon.
item.description: Evidence collected in secret Communist Party investigations, using threats and torture, is often repurposed for criminal cases, Human Rights Watch said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Living With Racism in Australia
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Melbourne, Australia, protesting last month against the United States president-elect, Donald J. Trump.
item.description: My family was welcomed here from Cambodia. Now the United Nations condemns our politicians’ “xenophobic hate speech.”
item.dc:creator: ALICE PUNG

item.title: Editorial: Gambia Finally Rejects Its Tyrant
item.media:description: Adama Barrow last week greeting supporters on the last day of the presidential campaign in Gambia.
item.description: The upset defeat of Yahya Jammeh is a triumph for democracy on a continent where autocratic rule is the norm.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Don’t Worry About the Italy Vote
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi speaking to the media in Rome, on Monday.
item.description: It was a rejection of the prime minister, not of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
